contentrichtext.text: [[File:André Morellet.jpg|thumb|200px|right|André Morellet]] '''André Morellet''' (7 March 1727 – 12 January 1819) was a [[France|French]] [[economist]] and writer. He was one of the last of the ''[[philosophes]]'', and in this character he figures in many memoirs, such as those of [[Madame de Rémusat]]. He was born at [[Lyon]], and educated by the [[Jesuit]]s there, and later at the [[Collège de Sorbonne|Sorbonne]]. He took holy orders, but without much conviction. [[Voltaire]] called him "''L'Abbé Mords-les''" ("''Father Bite-them''"), because of his ready and biting wit. His most notable works were a smart pamphlet in answer to [[Charles Palissot]]'s scurrilous play ''Les Philosophes'' (which procured him a short stay in the [[Bastille]] for an alleged [[libel]] on Palissot's patroness, the princesse de Robecq), and a reply to [[Ferdinando Galiani]]'s ''Commerce des blés'' (1770). In 1765, Morellet produced a French translation of ''[[On Crimes and Punishments]]''. His translation was widely criticized for the liberties he took with the text.<ref name="Beccariadi)1986">{{cite book|author1=Cesare Beccaria|title=On Crimes And Punishments|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=I_OWHbwVzcEC&pg=PR17|accessdate=21 July 2012|year=1986|publisher=Hackett|isbn=978-0-915145-97-3|page=17}}</ref> He was a contributor to the [[Encyclopédie]] and a friend of [[Benjamin Franklin]].<ref name="Isaacson2004">{{cite book|author=Walter Isaacson|title=Benjamin Franklin: An American Life|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=L64OOJGaCKIC&pg=PA364|accessdate=21 July 2012|date=4 May 2004|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-7432-5807-4|page=364}}</ref> Later, he made himself useful in quasi-diplomatic communications with [[England|English]] statesmen, and was pensioned and also elected a member of the [[Académie française]] in 1785. A year before his death in Paris, he brought out four volumes of ''Mélanges de littérature et de philosophie du XVIII<sup>e</sup> siècle'', composed chiefly of selections from his former publications, and after his death appeared his valuable ''Mémoires sur le XVIII<sup>e</sup> siècle et la Révolution'' (2 vols., 1821). His semi-satirical translation of [[Nicolau Aymerich]]'s ''[[Directorium Inquisitorum]]'' was an influencing factor in the cessation of some of the [[Roman Catholic Church]]'s more [[Inquisition|inquisitorial]] practices. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{1911}} **The ''Britannica'' in turn cites: ***A bibliography of his numerous works is given in [[Joseph Marie Quérard|Quérard]]'s ''La France littéraire'', vol. vi.; see also [[Charles Augustin Sainte-Beuve|Sainte-Beuve]], ''Causeries du lundi'', vol. i. {{Académie française Seat 5}} {{D'Holbach's Coterie}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Morellet, Andre | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 7 March 1727 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Lyon | DATE OF DEATH = 12 January 1819 | PLACE OF DEATH = Paris }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Morellet, Andre}} [[Category:1727 births]] [[Category:1819 deaths]] [[Category:People from Lyon]] [[Category:University of Paris alumni]] [[Category:Members of the Académie française]] [[Category:Physiocrats]] [[Category:18th-century economists]]
